div.p:
BEing very Å¿enÅ¿ible of a great Injury lately done mee, by the extreme falÅ¿e printing of a Å¿mal TreatiÅ¿e of my CompoÅ¿ing, Å¿toln out without my conÅ¿ent, and hearing accidentally that Å¿ome part of this alÅ¿o had paÅ¿Å¿ed the PreÅ¿Å¿e, I thought good for the preventing of the like wrong to Å¿tay the forwardneÅ¿Å¿e of the printer untill I had reviewed and corrected it by mine owne Notes. For my part, I Å¿hould have been contented altogether to have reÅ¿trained it, if I might, But now Å¿eeing it muÅ¿t abroad, I Å¿hall not bee aÅ¿hamed to let it beare my name, and owne the errors of it my Å¿elf (thoÅ¿e

Some there are yet Å¿urviving that heard this Argument about thirty yeeres Å¿ince in the Commons-HouÅ¿e of Parliament, but it hath now extended it Å¿elfe beyond the probable proportion of a Speech or Argument, by the inÅ¿ertion of many Records and Acts of Parliament more at large, which at the delivery of it, were but meerely quoted.

And you Å¿hall Å¿ee herein how the policy of active Princes hath by many waies attempted to undermine thoÅ¿e Fortifications which the wiÅ¿dom of our AnceÅ¿tors hath rayÅ¿ed to maintaine themÅ¿elves from this kinde of AÅ¿Å¿ault. You Å¿hall Å¿ee with how great difficulty their prevailing was withÅ¿tood: And (which is the glory of Truth) you Å¿hall finde thoÅ¿e deÅ¿ignes which were laid to overthrow our Right, mainly to make for the evidence and confirmation of it. For, whatever unjuÅ¿t ImpoÅ¿itions were either exacted by a pretended lawfullneÅ¿Å¿e, or Å¿et up by a commanding power, were by complaint in Parliaments preÅ¿ently following taken down, and remain on Record as (witneÅ¿Å¿es againÅ¿t themÅ¿elves) unlawfull, and againÅ¿t our Libertie.

div.p: THe QueÅ¿tion now in debate amongÅ¿t us, is, Whether his Mtie. may, by his Prerogative Royall (without aÅ¿Å¿ent of Parliament) at his own will and pleaÅ¿ure, lay a new Charge or ImpoÅ¿ition upon Merchandizes, to be brought into, or out of this Kingdome of England; and enforce Merchants to pay the Å¿ame.

I MuÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e, that when this Point was firÅ¿t Å¿tirred mongÅ¿t us, and that wee, not contented to Å¿eeke redreÅ¿Å¿e for the exceÅ¿Å¿e of the preÅ¿ent ImpoÅ¿itions, reÅ¿olved to proceed farther, by calling his MajeÅ¿ties right of ImpoÅ¿ing into queÅ¿tion, I was very Å¿ory: for I Å¿aw we were then in a faire way to have obteined a very great abatement of the ImpoÅ¿itions that now
are; and beÅ¿ides, we had his MajeÅ¿ties promiÅ¿e never to lay any more but in Parliament time, by the advice and free conÅ¿ent of his Subjects, repayring hither from all parts of the Realme; This hope of a preÅ¿ent eaÅ¿e, and gracious promiÅ¿e for the time to come, gave me (I confeÅ¿Å¿e) a full Å¿atisfaction; eÅ¿pecially, Å¿eeing I was confidently perÅ¿waded that his MajeÅ¿ties right to impoÅ¿e was very cleere and not to be diÅ¿puted, and that therfore by drawing into queÅ¿tion the right, wee might give his MajeÅ¿ty juÅ¿t occaÅ¿ion to withdraw from us his gracious purpoÅ¿e of the preÅ¿ent abatement, as alÅ¿o his promiÅ¿e for the time to come: For Syr, when the CaÅ¿e of Bates (who as you know was called into queÅ¿tion for refuÅ¿ing to pay the ImpoÅ¿ition laid upon Currans) was argued in the Exchequer, in which CaÅ¿e his MajeÅ¿ties right to ImpoÅ¿e, was Å¿olemnly diÅ¿puted (and there reÅ¿olved for his MajeÅ¿ty) I was then preÅ¿ent at all the Arguments both at the Bar and at the Bench; And I doe confeÅ¿Å¿e that by the weighty and unanÅ¿werable reaÅ¿ons (as I then conceived them) of thoÅ¿e grave and reverend Judges, Fl â¢ ming Ch. Bar. Clarke. Savil. Å¿itting in their Å¿eate of JuÅ¿tice, I was much perÅ¿waded; but by thoÅ¿e many records vouched by them, I was altogether overcome, and as it were vanquiÅ¿h't to yeeld to them; for Syr, Ratio Å¿uadet, Anthoritas vincit: But though I were then, and when the QueÅ¿tion was firÅ¿t moved in this houÅ¿e, very confident, yet as you Å¿hall perceive anon, I
was not very conÅ¿tant in that opinion; for being (amongÅ¿t others) imployed by this houÅ¿e to make Å¿earch in the Exchequer for Records, which (by the practiÅ¿e of former ages) might guide our judgements in this weighty point, and having diligently collected the Arguments made in the Exchequer, and not only Å¿o, but compared my owne collections with Reports thereof made by divers other of my friends, & finding that Å¿ome of the Records urged in thoÅ¿e Arguments were untruly vouched (and many miÅ¿aplyed) I then began to Å¿tagger in my opinion, and preÅ¿ently fell to examine the weight of the ReaÅ¿ons which had been alledged, which in my poore cenÅ¿ure, I found not of Å¿trength Å¿ufficient (without the full concurrence of cleere PreÅ¿idents of former times) to maintaine the Judgement given, or my Opinion grounded thereupon: And therefore (Syr) In love to the truth I did forÅ¿ake my former opinion as erroneous, and do now embrace the contrary, that is, That his MajeÅ¿ty hath no right to impoÅ¿e, and Å¿o am now become a convert. ThoÅ¿e ReaÅ¿ons that moved mee thus to change, and the weakeneÅ¿Å¿e which I diÅ¿covered in the ReaÅ¿ons alledged againÅ¿t the opinion which I now hold; I will, with your patience, open unto you, and will therein follow the commandement of ChriÅ¿t to Peter. Beeing converted, Å¿eeke to convert my brethren,

As touching the Judgement in the Exchequer
Å¿tanding yet in force, Å¿o often caÅ¿t as a block in our way, though I much reverence the perÅ¿ons of thoÅ¿e yet living, and the memory of thoÅ¿e that are with God, who gave the Judgement: Yet Å¿eeing (as I hope I Å¿hall bee able evidently to prove) the Å¿ame to bee againÅ¿t the great Charter of our Liberties, I can eÅ¿teeme no otherwiÅ¿e of it then the Statute of 25.Ed. 1. cap. 10. pronounceth of all Å¿uch Judgements, that is; that it is void and to be held for nought. Thus much I thought good to Å¿ay by way of Preamble or Introduction to the matter: now (by your favors) I will enter into the debate of the QueÅ¿tion; in handling of which I will purpoÅ¿ely avoid the repetition of any thing that hath been Å¿poken by any man that hath argued before, as knowing in what preÅ¿ence I Å¿peake. That I may the better convey my Å¿elfe through my Argument, and be the better conceived of you that are to heare me, I will divide that which I have to Å¿ay into certain parts, which I will proÅ¿ecute in order.
FirÅ¿t, I hold it neceÅ¿Å¿ary to conÅ¿ider whether CuÅ¿tom were due to the king by the Common-Law.
Secondly, admitting it to bee due by the Common-Law, whether it were a Å¿umme certain, not to be increaÅ¿ed at the kings pleaÅ¿ure, or otherwiÅ¿e.

Thirdly, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing that by the Common-Law the king might, by way of impoÅ¿ition,
have increaÅ¿ed his CuÅ¿tom at his owne will, by his abÅ¿olute power, without aÅ¿Å¿ent in Parliament, whether or no hee bee not bound to the contrary by Acts of Parliament; In the handling of which part, I will conÅ¿ider the Å¿trength of every Act of Parliament hitherto vouched to this purpoÅ¿e, anÅ¿wering, as I goe, Å¿uch objections as have been made againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e Statutes by Å¿uch as have mainteined that the king is not bound by them. I will alÅ¿o add a Statute or two as yet not remembred by any. LaÅ¿tly, I will diÅ¿cover unto you the weakneÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿uch ReaÅ¿ons as have been made in maintenance of the Kings right to ImpoÅ¿e; in the proÅ¿ecuting of which parts I will (as occaÅ¿ion is offered) give Å¿ome anÅ¿were to that which hath been laÅ¿t Å¿poken; as knowing it to be expected at my hands.By Sir Robert Hitcham.

FirÅ¿t then to conÅ¿ider Whether there were by the Common-Law any duty belonging to the King upon Merchandize to be caried into or out of the kingdom, known by the name of CuÅ¿tom. Though the mainteinance of CuÅ¿tome to be due by the Common-Law be a point of Å¿uch conÅ¿equence to them that mainteined the Kings right to ImpoÅ¿e, as without the upholding of which their opinion (as I conceive) is not Å¿o much as colourably to be mainteined, and that to maintein the Å¿ame it be not at all neceÅ¿Å¿ary to induce my concluÅ¿ion; and although to admit it, it may Å¿eem perhaps no good policy of Argument, but
rather a great diÅ¿advantage to me to admit that, without which the contrary part cannot uphold their opinion, and which being admitted cannot make any thing for me; yet becauÅ¿e we are here not as Arguers at the Bar, but as Judges in a high-Court, and that all our ends tend to the diÅ¿covery of the truth: I will therefore not only admit it, but will maintein it as well as I can.

That CuÅ¿tom is due by the Common-Law I collect,That there was ever Å¿ome CuÅ¿tome due by the Common Law. firÅ¿t by the name thereof, for though at this day it bee (and Å¿o hath beene for more then 350 yeeres as I Å¿hall have occaÅ¿ion more fully anon to open unto you) called in our law-Latin CuÅ¿tuma, yet in ancient time it had no other name here amongÅ¿t us (for I meane not to wander into forreign-learning) then ConÅ¿uetudo, as may appeare by the Statute of Magna Charta cap. 30. Per rectas & antiquas ConÅ¿uetudines (for I Å¿hall anon directly prove unto you that ConÅ¿uetudo in that place is not to be underÅ¿tood, a uÅ¿age, as hath been Å¿aid; but in that Å¿ence which I, take it.) This name ConÅ¿uetudo in the Å¿ame Å¿enÅ¿e is alÅ¿o found in many ancient Records brought into this houÅ¿e upon the late Å¿earch; That this name then ConÅ¿uetudo, which implies an approved continuance without a known beginning Å¿hould by the Common-Law be given to this Revenue more then to any other Revenue belonging to the King; nay, that this terme which is the common and generall
name to all common and approved uÅ¿ages, of what nature or kinde Å¿oever Å¿hould be applied to this dutie rather then to any other amongÅ¿t all the ancient uÅ¿ages and CuÅ¿tomes which the Common-Law imbraceth, cannot but denote the great antiquity thereof, and more then Å¿o, the allowance and approbation thereof by the Common-Law; for doubtleÅ¿Å¿e, if, beÅ¿ide the antiquity of this dutie, the Common-Law had not alÅ¿o alowed the reaÅ¿onableneÅ¿Å¿e of it, and in a manner the neceÅ¿Å¿ity of it, it would never have denoted it unto us by this name of excellency above all other CuÅ¿tomes which require reaÅ¿onablenes as well as antiquity: Therfore doubtleÅ¿Å¿e this duty, thus favored, is a Childe of the Common-Law; nay farther, it is of the very eÅ¿Å¿ence of a CuÅ¿tome to have his only beginning by alowance of the Common-Law; for that which beginneth by private contract of partie, or by Act of Parliament, & dependeth not wholly upon the alowance of the Common-Law (by one of which three waies, all things conÅ¿iderable in Law, have their commencements) cannot bee called or bee a CuÅ¿tome, in Name or Deede; moreover conÅ¿idering that this CuÅ¿tome is not limited to any one place within the Realme, wee Å¿hall Å¿o little neede to be curious in affirming it to bee due by the Common-Law, as wee may boldly pronounce it to be part of the Common-Law it Å¿elfe. Thus you Å¿ee that the very name
ConÅ¿uetudo proves CuÅ¿tome to bee a dutie by Common-Law: To this may bee added that Magna Charta cap. 30. which (Statute was made little more then 150 yeeres after the ConqueÅ¿t) termeth this not only ConÅ¿uetudo (which as I have Å¿aid, implies Antiquity beyond all remembrance of a beginning) but Antiqua ConÅ¿uetudo; not onely CuÅ¿tome, but old and ancient CuÅ¿tome. And in compariÅ¿on to this old CuÅ¿tome due at Common-Law, the CuÅ¿tome upon Staple Commodities, given or increaÅ¿ed by act of Parliament, 3 E. 1. not printed, was called Nova ConÅ¿uetudo: Before the making of which Statute of 3 E. 1. you may further Å¿ee, that CuÅ¿tome was due: For an. 52. H. 3. in the Statute of the Exchequer, printed, you may read, that the Collectors of the CuÅ¿tome of Wools were to yeeld their accompt twice every yeere into the Exchequer. But that which moÅ¿t of all moveth me to beleeve that this duty was and is due by the Common-Law, is this; That in all CaÅ¿es where the Common-Law putteth the King to Å¿uÅ¿taine Charge for the protection of the Subject, it alwayes yeeldeth him out of the thing protected Å¿ome gaine towards the maintenance of the Charge: As for the protection of Wards, Lunatiques, and Ideots, the profits of their Lands; For the maintenance of the Courts of JuÅ¿tice, it giveth him Fines for purchaÅ¿e of Originall writs, and Fines pro licentia Concordandi, which in Å¿uppoÅ¿ition of Law are no other
than Fines paid for not proceeding according to the Å¿urety by pledges, put in upon purchaÅ¿e of the Originall; and for troubling without cauÅ¿e the Kings JuÅ¿tices, who are maintained in their places at the Kings charge: There are many the like profits of Court given by the Common-Law to the King for the maintenance of his charge in the adminiÅ¿tring of JuÅ¿tice.

This obÅ¿ervation, which might be further proved by divers other inÅ¿tances in things of other nature, maketh me to think, that becauÅ¿e the Common-Law expecteth that the King Å¿hould protect Merchants in their Trades, by maintaining, repairing, and fortifying the Havens at home; by clearing the Sea of Pirates and Enemies in their paÅ¿Å¿age; and by maintaining AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors abroad to treate with forreigne Princes upon all Å¿uch occaÅ¿ions: That it alÅ¿o giveth him out of Merchandizes exported and imported, Å¿ome profit for the Å¿uÅ¿tentation of this publique charge; otherwiÅ¿e were the Law very unreaÅ¿onable and unjuÅ¿t. So as to prove that by the Common-Law CuÅ¿tome is due to the King, I Å¿hall need to Å¿ay no more; eÅ¿pecially conÅ¿idering it hath not onely been yeelded to, but proved by thoÅ¿e which maintain a contrary ConcluÅ¿ion. I will therefore proceed to my Å¿econd ConÅ¿ideration: Whether that profit upon Merchandizes, which the Common-Law for theÅ¿e reÅ¿pects gave unto the King, were a duty certaine, not to be increaÅ¿ed or inhaunced at the
Kings will and pleaÅ¿ure, without a common aÅ¿Å¿ent in Parliament? Or otherwiÅ¿e, Whether the Common Law hath left an abÅ¿olute power in the King, to demand in this caÅ¿e more or leÅ¿Å¿e at his owne pleaÅ¿ure, and to compell his Subjects to pay it? The reÅ¿olving of which queÅ¿tion will as I conceive, make an end of this controverÅ¿ie between us; for what are theÅ¿e ImpoÅ¿itions which wee complaine of, other than the enhauncing of the CuÅ¿tome by the Kings abÅ¿olute pleaÅ¿ure?

That this duty given by the Common-Law (as I have proved) unto the King,That CuÅ¿tome due by Common Law, was a Sum certain. was and is a duty certain, not to be enhaunced by the King at his owne pleaÅ¿ure, without aÅ¿Å¿ent Parliament, I hope I Å¿hall be able cleerly to prove unto you: In mainteinance of which, I will uÅ¿e Å¿ome Arguments of direct proofe, and others of great preÅ¿umption and probability.
